skill.name: nx-workspace-patterns
skill.description: Configure and optimize Nx monorepo workspaces. Use when setting up Nx, configuring project boundaries, optimizing build caching, or implementing affected commands.
skill.summary: Configure and optimize Nx monorepo workspaces. Use when setting up Nx, configuring project boundarie...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only static documentation and configuration templates for Nx workspaces. No executable code, network access, file operations, or data handling is present.

content.value_statement: Nx workspaces can become slow and inconsistent without clear standards. This skill provides templates to set boundaries, caching, and affected workflows.
actual_capabilities: Provide nx.json template with cacheable operations and target defaults
Provide project.json template for web app build, serve, test, and lint targets
Provide ESLint module boundary rules using @nx/enforce-module-boundaries
Provide custom generator example for feature libraries
Provide GitHub Actions CI workflow using affected commands
Provide remote caching examples for Nx Cloud and S3
limitations: Does not execute Nx commands or modify files
Does not validate existing workspace configuration
Templates require adaptation to specific project paths and tags
Does not manage cloud credentials or secrets

use_cases.title: Set up new Nx workspace
use_cases.description: Apply recommended structure, tags, and caching defaults for a new monorepo with proper boundaries.

use_cases.title: Optimize CI pipelines
use_cases.description: Use affected commands and caching patterns to reduce build times and resource usage.

use_cases.title: Enforce architecture rules
use_cases.description: Define module boundaries to prevent circular dependencies and maintain clean architecture.

prompt_templates.title: Basic nx.json setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Give me a minimal nx.json with cacheable operations for build, test, lint, and e2e with target defaults.

prompt_templates.title: React project configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a project.json for a React app with webpack executor for build, serve, test, and lint targets.

prompt_templates.title: Module boundary enforcement
prompt_templates.prompt: Create ESLint rules that enforce appâ†’featureâ†’uiâ†’util dependency hierarchy with scope restrictions.

prompt_templates.title: CI optimization workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a GitHub Actions workflow that uses nx affected commands for lint, test, build, and e2e in parallel.

output_examples.input: I need to set up module boundaries for my Nx monorepo
output: Define library types: feature, ui, data-access, util, shell
Create ESLint rules enforcing type:app can only import from feature, ui, data-access, util
Restrict type:ui to only depend on ui and util libraries
Add scope-based boundaries to isolate web, api, and shared code

best_practices: Use consistent tags and enforce them with module boundaries from day one
Enable caching and affected commands early to maximize CI performance gains
Keep libraries focused with single responsibility and clear documentation
anti_patterns: Creating circular dependencies between libraries that violate the hierarchy
Running full test suites when nx affected could test only changed code
Over-granularizing into too many tiny libraries without clear purpose

faq.question: Is this compatible with current Nx versions?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns target modern Nx workspaces using project.json configuration format.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides templates and guidance only, not automated file changes or validation.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing CI?
faq.answer: Yes, the workflow examples work with any CI system that can run nx commands.

faq.question: Does it access my data or secrets?
faq.answer: No, it does not read files, environment variables, or make network calls.

faq.question: What should I check if Nx commands fail?
faq.answer: Verify Nx version compatibility, project.json paths, and cache directory permissions.

faq.question: How does this compare to official Nx docs?
faq.answer: It condenses common patterns into ready-to-use templates for faster setup.
